UML can be used as much or as little as you like. Martin Fowler describes three common ways that people tend to use UML:
But UML modeling is not just about diagrams; it's about capturing your system as a modelâ€”the diagrams are actually just windows into that model.
Well, the first thing to understand is that your model sits behind your modeling tool and diagrams as a collection of elements.

Some projects can get away with less modeling. In fact, some commercial industries find that too much modeling is cumbersome and slows down productivity. For such projects, it makes sense to use UML as a sketch and have your model contain some architectural diagrams and a few class and sequence diagrams to illustrate
The problem with this method is that if a change in requirements occurs, the impact can be devastating.

highlighted_text: Encapsulation of operations and data within an object is probably the single most powerful and useful part of the object-oriented approach to system design. Encapsulation enables a class to hide the inner details of how it works from the outside worldâ€”like the electrics from the example guitar classâ€”and only expose the operations and data that it chooses to make accessible.

The word "flow" was mentioned several times previously and you may askâ€”what's flowing? The answer depends on the context. Typically, it's the flow of control from one action to the next: one action executes to completion, then gives up its control to the next action. In later sections you'll see that, along with control, objects can flow through an activity.
They are statements that evaluate to true or false
